repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
I found these convenient for debugging, so I figured I'd offer them to the repo.

That being said, they were written for functionality rather than readability and violate [some people's style recommendations](https://docs.python-guide.org/writing/style/#explicit-code).

comment_data.body: ' i' and ' j'  are good names for index/integer loop variables, but bad names for everything else. This looks more like an `arg_name`. Also, `args` is probably just `arg_names`, not argument values.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -117,6 +117,25 @@ def wrapper(self, string, *args, **kwargs):
 # Classes that represent the debug information
 # Don't rename the parameters of these classes, they come directly from the XML
 
+def simple_repr(self, renamed={}, skip=[], state=True):
+    import inspect
+    args = tuple(inspect.signature(self.__init__).parameters)
+    args = tuple(renamed[i] if i in renamed else i for i in args)

@@ -165,6 +190,25 @@ def __init__(self,
 
 # General purpose classes
 
+def frame_str(f):
+    res = str(f) + "\n"
+    for i in filter(lambda x: not x.startswith("__"), dir(f)):
+        val = getattr(f, i)

comment_data.body:
`f` seems worth naming `frame` to avoid mental references to `file` or `function`.
```suggestion
def frame_str(frame):
    res = str(frame) + "\n"
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,6 +190,25 @@ def __init__(self,
 
 # General purpose classes
 
+def frame_str(f):
+    res = str(f) + "\n"

comment_data.body: You seem to be stripping the last line here. Why? Please add a comment.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,6 +190,25 @@ def __init__(self,
 
 # General purpose classes
 
+def frame_str(f):
+    res = str(f) + "\n"
+    for i in filter(lambda x: not x.startswith("__"), dir(f)):
+        val = getattr(f, i)
+        if callable(val):
+            try:
+                val = val()
+            except Exception as e:
+                pass
+
+        if type(val) in [gdb.Symtab_and_line, gdb.Symbol, gdb.Symtab]:
+            val = frame_str(val).rsplit("\n", 1)[0].replace("\n", "\n\t")

comment_data.body:
I'm not sure if we want ordering here in order to get reproducible results? (EDIT: Probably yes, also to make the output easier to skim over. Let's use `sorted()`.)
```suggestion
    local = ()
    if state:
        local = tuple(sorted(arg_name for arg_name in vars(self).keys() if arg_name not in args))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -117,6 +117,25 @@ def wrapper(self, string, *args, **kwargs):
 # Classes that represent the debug information
 # Don't rename the parameters of these classes, they come directly from the XML
 
+def simple_repr(self, renamed={}, skip=[], state=True):
+    import inspect
+    args = tuple(inspect.signature(self.__init__).parameters)
+    args = tuple(renamed[i] if i in renamed else i for i in args)
+    local = tuple(filter(lambda x: x not in args, vars(self).keys())) \
+        if state else ()

comment_data.body:
This doesn't feel like a tuple, more like a list.
```suggestion
    return "".join([
            self.__class__.__name__,
            "(", ",".join(equals("\n\t\t", args)), "\n\t)",
            *equals("\nself.", local)
        ])
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -117,6 +117,25 @@ def wrapper(self, string, *args, **kwargs):
 # Classes that represent the debug information
 # Don't rename the parameters of these classes, they come directly from the XML
 
+def simple_repr(self, renamed={}, skip=[], state=True):
+    import inspect
+    args = tuple(inspect.signature(self.__init__).parameters)
+    args = tuple(renamed[i] if i in renamed else i for i in args)
+    local = tuple(filter(lambda x: x not in args, vars(self).keys())) \
+        if state else ()
+
+    def equals(prefix, attrs):
+        for i in (j for j in attrs if j not in skip):
+            attr = repr(getattr(self, i))
+            yield prefix + i + " = " + attr.replace("\n", "\n\t\t")
+
+    return "".join((
+            self.__class__.__name__,
+            "(", ",".join(equals("\n\t\t", args)), "\n\t)",
+            *equals("\nself.", local)
+        ))

comment_data.body:
Let's avoid mutable default arguments.
```suggestion
def simple_repr(self, renamed=None, skip=(), state=True):
```

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    init_attrs = tuple(renamed.get(arg, arg) for arg in init_arg_names) if renamed else init_arg_names
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -117,6 +117,61 @@ def wrapper(self, string, *args, **kwargs):
 # Classes that represent the debug information
 # Don't rename the parameters of these classes, they come directly from the XML
 
+def simple_repr(self, renamed={}, skip=[], state=True):
+    """prints out all instance variables needed to recreate an object
+
+    Following the python convention for __repr__, this function prints all the
+    information stored in an instance as opposed to its class. The working
+    assumption is that most initialization arguments are stored as a property
+    using the same name.
+
+    The object contents are displayed as the initialization call followed by,
+    optionally, the value of each of the instance's properties in the form:
+    ```
+    ClassName(
+            init_arg_1 = "repr of some example str",
+            ...
+        )
+    self.state_based_property = ...
+    ```
+
+    Function arguments:
+    self        Instance to be represented
+
+    renamed     Dictionary of initialization arguments that are stored under a
+                different property name in the form { argument: property }
+
+    skip        List of instance variables not to be listed as properties.
+                Computed properties are already skipped.
+                Only changes behavior if `state` argument is True (default).
+
+    state       Boolean representing whether properties outside the
+                initialization parameters should be printed (self.prop = ...).
+                Using `False` may make the class more amenable to recursive repr
+    """
+    import inspect
+    init_arg_names = tuple(inspect.signature(self.__init__).parameters)
+    init_attrs = tuple(renamed.get(arg, arg) for arg in init_arg_names)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
            # strip last line since it will get added on at the end of the loop
            value = frame_repr(value).rstrip("\n").replace("\n", "\n\t")
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,6 +226,45 @@ def __init__(self,
 
 # General purpose classes
 
+def frame_repr(frame):
+    """Returns a string representing the internal state of a provided GDB frame
+
+    Created to serve as GDB.Frame.__repr__ for debugging purposes. GDB has many
+    layers of abstraction separating the state of the debugger from the
+    corresponding source code. This prints a tree of instance properties,
+    expanding the values for Symtab_and_line, Symbol, and Symtab.
+
+    Most of these properties require computation to determine, meaning much of
+    relevant info is behind a monad. Rather than list which properties are worth
+    printing, we assume that frames are mostly a read-only context and that any
+    function without an argument is idempotent. That is to say, every function
+    is called without arguments and any that don't throw an exception are added
+    to the output.
+
+    Arguments
+    frame       The GDB.Frame instance to be represented as a string
+    """
+    res = str(frame) + "\n"
+    for attribute in sorted(dir(frame)):
+        if attribute.startswith("__"):
+            continue
+        value = getattr(frame, attribute)
+        if callable(value):
+            try:
+                value = value()
+            except Exception as e:
+                pass
+
+        if type(value) in [gdb.Symtab_and_line, gdb.Symbol, gdb.Symtab]:
+            # strip last line since it will get added on at the end of the loop
+            value = frame_repr(value).strip("\n").replace("\n", "\n\t")

comment_data.body:
This is an unusual spelling. You'd normally expect `is` for a type check like this rather than `==`, but why not just use the normal `isinstance()`?
```suggestion
        if isinstance(value, int):
```

+def frame_repr(frame):

+            # strip last line since it will get added on at the end of the loop
+            value = frame_repr(value).strip("\n").replace("\n", "\n\t")
+        res += attribute + ": "
+        if type(value) == int:

comment_data.body:
Calling arbitrary methods on frame objects seems unexpected and risky if the goal is something as obviously read-only as printing out their state. I read the docstring and your reasoning, but it doesn't really convince me that this is a good idea. Frame objects have been subject to major changes recently and in the past, so we should try to make little assumptions about their behaviour.

I'd rather see a whitelist of safe and relevant properties to be printed. This is only for printing, after all. If users want more information, they can query it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,6 +226,45 @@ def __init__(self,
 
 # General purpose classes
 
+def frame_repr(frame):
+    """Returns a string representing the internal state of a provided GDB frame
+
+    Created to serve as GDB.Frame.__repr__ for debugging purposes. GDB has many
+    layers of abstraction separating the state of the debugger from the
+    corresponding source code. This prints a tree of instance properties,
+    expanding the values for Symtab_and_line, Symbol, and Symtab.
+
+    Most of these properties require computation to determine, meaning much of
+    relevant info is behind a monad. Rather than list which properties are worth
+    printing, we assume that frames are mostly a read-only context and that any
+    function without an argument is idempotent. That is to say, every function
+    is called without arguments and any that don't throw an exception are added
+    to the output.
+
+    Arguments
+    frame       The GDB.Frame instance to be represented as a string
+    """
+    res = str(frame) + "\n"
+    for attribute in sorted(dir(frame)):
+        if attribute.startswith("__"):
+            continue
+        value = getattr(frame, attribute)
+        if callable(value):
+            try:
+                value = value()
+            except Exception as e:
+                pass

@@ -137,6 +139,26 @@ def test_CythonFunction(self):
         self.assertEqual(self.spam_func.lineno, expected_lineno)
         self.assertEqual(sorted(self.spam_func.locals), list('abcd'))
 
+class TestReprMethods(DebugTestCase):
+
+    def test_simple_repr(self):
+        test_class = libcython.CythonModule
+        num_args = len(inspect.signature(test_class).parameters)
+        lorem_ipsum = random.Random(0)
+        filler_args = (lorem_ipsum.randbytes(8) for _ in range(num_args))
+        instance = test_class(*filler_args)
+        recreated = eval("libcython." + repr(instance))
+        self.assertEqual(pickle.dumps(instance), pickle.dumps(recreated))
+
+

@@ -137,6 +139,26 @@ def test_CythonFunction(self):
         self.assertEqual(self.spam_func.lineno, expected_lineno)
         self.assertEqual(sorted(self.spam_func.locals), list('abcd'))
 
+class TestReprMethods(DebugTestCase):
+
+    def test_simple_repr(self):
+        test_class = libcython.CythonModule
+        num_args = len(inspect.signature(test_class).parameters)
+        lorem_ipsum = random.Random(0)
+        filler_args = (lorem_ipsum.randbytes(8) for _ in range(num_args))
+        instance = test_class(*filler_args)
+        recreated = eval("libcython." + repr(instance))
+        self.assertEqual(pickle.dumps(instance), pickle.dumps(recreated))
+
+
+    def test_frame_repr(self):
+        # check that frame_repr's function expansion is idempotent
+        beginline = 'import os'
+
+        self.break_and_run(beginline)
+        frame = gdb.selected_frame()
+        self.assertEqual(libcython.frame_repr(frame),
+                         libcython.frame_repr(frame))

commit.message: add repr methods to GDB classes for debugging purposes

longer variable names, sorted fields, list instead of tuple

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

sorted fields

batched suggestions didn't work

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

list instead of tuple

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>
upgrade macos version because brew dropped support
